JOHN Brayford's thumping 83rd minute header secured another precious victory for the Brewers as they eased further away from the bottom four

The Albion skipper threw himself at substitute Joe Powell's teasing free kick on 83 minutes to put the Brewers back in front after Tom Hamer's first Burton Albion goal had been cancelled out by Jack Payne in a fast flowing first half.

Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink opted for just the one change from the side that gained a valuable point at Accrington on Friday. With Michael Bostwick available again having missed out at the Wham Stadium, the former Lincoln defender came straight bakcv into the side at the expense of Josh Earl who returned to the bench.

The Swindon side contained a couple of familiar faces with Lee Camp, a former loan signing back in 2003, and Matty Palmer both lining up against the Brewers, Palmer handed the captain's armband for his return to the Pirelli.

Albion got off to a lively start hemming their visitors deep inside their own half and Swindon were forced into a very early change when Ellis Iandolo injured himself in a challenge right on the touchline that resulted in him taking no further part, Jonathan Grounds slotting into the centre of the Town defence.

The Brewers continued to look for an early breakthrough and it almost came on ten minutes, Lucas Akins crossing for Sean Clare to glance a header towards goal that was easy for Camp to gather in.

Swindon broke forwards and a speculative long range effort from Scott Twine was straight at Ben Garratt who then had to come to the edge of his area to head away under pressure from Brett Pitman.

A good chance came Albion's way on 16 minutes, Akins nipping in to intercept a weak header from Paul Caddis back to Camp but from a difficult angle he could only find the side netting.

Jonny Smith almost notched against his former loan side on 21 minutes, a route one ball out from Garratt eventually landing at his feet and an early taken shot forced Campt to beat the ball away with Clare unable to keep the rebound on target.

Smith may not have found the target himself but his next action was a crucial assist on 26 minutes swinging in a perfect free kick for HAMER to rise highest and head beyond Camp into the corner of the net.

Albion looked to add a second but it was the visitors who got themselves back on terms on 35 minutes. No pressure was applied as Dominic Thompson crossed from the left and although the initial delivery was cleared the ball fell for PAYNE who measured a curling 25-yard left footer into the corner of the goal.

Half time: Burton Albion 1-1 Swindon Town

Payne tried his luck again in the early second half exchanges when Bostwick's attempted clearance landed at his feet and he hit an early rising effort that cleared to goal relatively comfortable. Payne was becoming quite influential and a run deep into the Burton box almost resulted in a second goal for the visitors as his low ball found Brett Pitman but Hayden Carter was on the line to deny him a goal.

The visitors were looking the more dangerous side and Twine's long range effort midway through the half forced a scrambling save from Garratt before Brett Pitman, under pressure in the box headed the rebound wide of the target.

Joe Powell was summonsed from the bench as Albion looked for a creative spark in the remaining minutes as Clare was replaced with over twenty minutes remaining.

AS Albion pushed to a 4-4-2 for the last ten minutes Powell found himself with a little gap on the edge of the box to shoot for goal but his effort was blocked as the visitors.

Powell was also instrumental as Albion hit the front again seven minutes from time. A booming free kick was sent into the mix and BRAYFORD was there to thump a header beyond Camps outstretched right hand into the goal.

Jonny Smith limped off gingerly in the closing minutes with what looked like a hamstring injury and Terry Taylor was brought on as Hasselbaink shuffled his pack around but Albion held out for a crucial victory over one of their relegation rivals to move eight points clear of danger.

Timeline

Paul Caddis’ football career might be best remembered for climbing 12 inches off the Reebok Stadium pitch to head the goal that saved Birmingham City from falling off a Championship cliff edge.

That was in 2014, when his injury time equaliser gave Lee Clark’s Blues a 2-2 draw against Bolton Wanderers and saved them from relegation to League One.

However, the former defender is now aiming to scale much higher peaks, three of them in fact, as he looks to raise money for a cause that in recent weeks has come very close to his heart and rather too close to home.

READ: ‘An insult', Deeney doubts, the takeover elephant and 18 more things we've learned

READ: Liam Daish opens up about his shock return and his plans for Blues' academy

The 34-year-old, now a coach at Fleetwood Town, has committed to hiking up the highest mountains in Scotland, England and Wales, in the space of just 24 hours, to raise money for Diabetes UK and research company JDRF UK.

He has accepted the challenge after his daughter Summer last month spent three nights in a high dependency unit at Blackpool Victoria Hospital with a life-threatening condition that has changed the lives of the Caddis family.

The ‘horrible’ experience unfolded quickly. “The best way of describing it, she sort of lost her personality, her character,” Caddis said. “She is quite a lively, bright 10-year-old, very active and does gymnastics, dancing and all the school stuff, and she was just very tired – all the time.

“There was no sign of any infection, she didn’t have a temperature it was just a loss of personality. My wife eventually took her to the doctor, that was the Tuesday, we went back on the Friday and my wife said, ‘Nothing’s changed, her character is not getting better, she’s like a walking zombie.’

“So they took a finger-prick test, a healthy blood-sugar level is between four and seven, my daughter’s was up at 25-plus, her ketone level was 11-12-plus. My wife called me as I was preparing a training session for my under-16s at Fleetwood and said ‘The doctors are really worried, they want to blue-light her to hospital’.

“I met my wife and two girls at the hospital, Summer was quite down and quite weak, and before we knew it she was hooked up to monitors and drips and lying in a bed with 24-hour care for three days. No nurse or doctor would leave her in a room alone.

“She went into a state called DKA (diabetic ketoacidosis)and the quickest way to describe it is acid in the blood. It starts to attack the vital organs, it started attacking her pancreas, once that gets to a stage where it’s fought off, it then starts attacking the lungs, the kidneys and if it’s not treated immediately it’s a life-threatening disease. In most cases with children that’s how they find out they are diabetic because there are no key signs.

“After three days she came off the drips, three four days later she cracked a smile and that smile will live with my wife and I and our youngest daughter. As a father I just want to be my daughter’s hero, give her the answers she needs, I want to make her better but she was lying there and I was helpless. That was the hardest thing for me.

“She went in to hospital on the Friday and by the Saturday afternoon, I remember counting the finger-pricks and she had 74. I hated seeing it and it got to the stage where she was just offering her fingers but they were so frequent they ended up going to her heel just to get blood out. It was a horrible three days.”

Happily, a few weeks on Summer is out of hospital, back at school and learning to control Type 1 diabetes.

“Thankfully she is fine now. I am the first person to say I was completely ignorant of what diabetes was, I genuinely just thought you had to inject yourself and you went on with your day.

"But it’s not like that, you have got to count carbs, you have got to deal with low blood glucose levels at 2:30am with no explanation, you have got to deal with high blood-sugars, you have got to deal with signs of when your sugars are going high.

“For instance, my daughter is very placid, very calm, no problem at all, but we have noticed when her bloods are high she has started to answer back and she has never, ever done that. She starts to get a bit ratty, upset, emotional, and it’s simply because her bloods are high.

“It’s been a difficult three-four weeks but we are getting there, she has been a little trooper, she has been absolutely brilliant, she has started slowly taking her own injections, she is learning with it. “She is finding it difficult at times but the advice from the diabetes team is to let diabetes live with her, let diabetes fit around her life rather than her fitting around diabetes.

“Within five-six days of leaving hospital we were at Harry Potter World in London to show her she can still live a normal life. Now life just has to be planned, today she went to school and I have got to plan a packed lunch and write how many carbs everything is and how many units she needs. Everything has to be planned.

“We are living with it, listen there are worse-off people in the world but when it’s your own daughter it hits home a bit more.”

Even more planning will be required for the trek that lies ahead, the infamous Three Peaks Challenge.

“I’ll be honest I probably didn’t research it as much as I should because it turns out it’s pretty daunting. One of my mates has been in the army for 14 to 15 years and he says it’s one of the toughest things he’s done.

“It’s just to give a little bit back, I’ve been a professional athlete for 16 to 17 years and I wanted to do something active, something to train for. You go up Ben Nevis in Scotland, starting around 5pm, we travel through the night to Scafell Pike in the Lakes and straight after that we’ll head to Snowdon. “We are looking forward to it, we have raised over £3,000, the owner at Swindon Town actually donated £500 last night. The support has been unbelievable.

“We put something on social media and it’s just grown from there, it’s a cause that’s now very close to my heart – research into diabetes. The technology in the last five or six years has been unbelievable. I firmly believe maybe not in our lifetime or my daughter’s lifetime but they will find a cure.”

That really is a mountain worth climbing.

Paul Caddis is currently training with League One side Bradford City, as reported by The72 earlier today. Here are five things for the Bantams fans to know about him-

1. Scotland international- Caddis played once for Scotland’s Under-19’s as a youngster and went onto make 13 caps for their Under-21’s side. He then made his first and only ever senior cap when he came on as a late substitute against the Czech Republic.

2. Started out at Celtic- The 30-year-old rose through Celtic’s youth ranks and went onto play for their first-team 24 times as well as enjoying a loan spell at Dundee United in 2008.

3. Moved south in 2010- Swindon Town signed Caddis in August 2010 and he became a key player for the Robins. Caddis played a key part in their promotion to League One in 2012 was impressive for the County Ground side.

4. Was a hit at Birmingham- The Blues initially signed Caddis on loan in 2012 but the deal was made permanent after a year. He 159 games in all competitions for them and scored the goal to keep them in the Championship on the final day of the 2013/14 season.

5. Had recent spells in League One- Caddis left Birmingham in January 2017 and joined Bury in the third tier a month later. He spent the remainder of the 2016/17 season with the Shakers before joining their North-West rivals Blackburn Rovers in July 2017. He was part of the Rovers’ side who were promoted from League One last season, but he had his contract terminated by mutual consent in August.

Paul Caddis is an experienced player and would be a decent signing for a struggling Bradford City side.

Burton Albion manager Paul Peschisolido has been impressed by trialist keepers Ross Atkins and Bertrand Bossu.

After keeper Adam Legzdins' move to Derby was finalised, it looked likely Atkins would move in the opposite direction but Bossu's training ground form means Peschisolido now faces a tough decision.

Skipper John Brayford's thumping header gave Burton a crucial 2-1 victory over Swindon.

The full-back raced into the box to head home Joe Powell's free-kick with seven minutes to go to secure a first Burton win in five games after Tom Hamer's opener had been cancelled out by Jack Payne's fine finish.

Hamer's first Burton goal gave Albion the lead after 26 minutes - the left-back was fouled out wide and former Swindon loanee Jonny Smith sent in a tempting free-kick which Hamer rose highest to head home.

As Albion looked to double their advantage, they were pegged back 10 minutes before half-time.

A deep cross was only cleared as far as Payne, who lashed home a superb left-footed 25-yard effort into the corner beyond the reach of home keeper Ben Garratt.

Payne fired over early in the second half and Brett Pitman was denied by Hayden Carter on the line.

Scott Twine tested Garratt with a long-range effort which was beaten away, with Pitman heading the rebound wide.

The consensus at Birmingham City is that they go into Saturday’s FA Cup derby with West Bromwich Albion as underdogs but - according to Paul Caddis and Gary Rowett, not massive ones.

Championship Blues take on Premier League Baggies at St Andrew’s this weekend with the winner guaranteed a place in the last 16.

Whilst the match contains many features that could make it a classic, with only 17 rungs of the football ladder between the sides it can hardly be described as David and Goliath.

Indeed Caddis, who scored Blues’ goal in the 1-1 draw with Leeds last time out believes a Birmingham win would only qualify as a ‘minor upset’.

Check out photos from Blues' win over Blyth in the previous round

“It’s a good distraction for us and a big game for us,” the Scot said.

“It’s a local derby and everyone is looking forward to it, none more so than the fans.

“It’s the magic of the FA Cup and cup football is completely different, regardless of how you’re playing in the league.

“We will go into it fairly confident of pulling off what would be a minor upset - it wouldn’t be a major upset being just one league below.

“But the local derby gives it that little bit of edge and obviously the fans will especially be looking forward to it.

“You can understand why some Premier League clubs, with bigger squads, maybe don’t treat the FA Cup so seriously.

“But for teams like us it’s a chance to play in big games and a big experience for us.

“Hopefully we can win, get another Premier League club in the next round and keep going from there.”

Blues boss Rowett has been in the spotlight more this week than at any time since he took control at St Andrew’s, many commentators attracted by the outstanding turnaround he has brought to the club.

Birmingham have won eight and lost just two of his 13 games in charge, a miraculous record given the fact they were second bottom and had just been hammered 8-0 by Bournemouth when he arrived.

Things have changed considerably since then and in an interview with The Guardian Rowett echoed Caddis’s sentiments about the relationship between Blues and Albion.

“If Birmingham beat West Brom, it shouldn’t be a huge upset,” he said.

“Look at the size of both clubs, look at the current form of both teams, even though West Brom were always going to pick up under Tony Pulis because I think he’s a fantastic manager.”
